etymologies: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘enclose with stakes or pales’): from French empaler or medieval Latin impalare, from Latin in- ‘in’ + palus ‘a stake’

definitions: pierce or transfix with a sharp instrument

examples.text: his head was impaled on a pike and exhibited for all to see

shortDefinitions: transfix or pierce with sharp instrument

definitions: display (a coat of arms) side by side with another on the same shield, separated by a vertical line

examples.text: the impaled arms of her husband and her father

shortDefinitions: display coat of arms side by side with another on same shield

definitions: (of a coat of arms) adjoin (another coat of arms) on the same shield

examples.text: the arms of the order are impaling those of the sovereign

shortDefinitions: (of coat of arms) adjoin another coat of arms on same shield
